title: Stout shrubs, frequently planted as wind-breaks. Leaves large, evergreen, 5-7-lobed. Flowers axillary, on long peduncles. Calyx with an outer row of 3-6 leaflets

note: Leaves thick, 3-sided, smooth, 1-3 in. long. Flowers crimson, nearly sessile. Fruit edible. This is common on the coast.
title: Calyx lobes 5, unequal. Petals numerous, linear. Stamens indefinitely numerous. Capsule with as many cells as styles (4-20), usually 5, dehiscent at the top
Perennial, with stout, usually prostrate stems

note: either in racemes or panicles. Pedicels not jointed.
title: Calyx 5-toothed or entire. Petals 5, ovate. Stamens 5. Pistil with the ovary 2-5-celled, and the styles free or slightly united at base

note: long, leathery, clothed with white down on the lower surface, green and glabrous on the upper. Corolla rose-color, small.
title: Shrub 3 or 4 ft. high. Leaves oblong to oval, 1-2 in
Fruit a smooth berry with a solid seed. Southern California, especially in San Diego County
Stems forming a mat on the ground. Leavessmall, very glossy. Flowers in short, simple racemes. Fruit bright red and smooth when ripe
Shrub with smooth ever-R. Califor'nicum Hook. green Flowers rose-color, numerous

Shrub with bright-green deciduous leaves. Flowers large, fragrant, appearing after the leaves, in numerous umbels. Corolla viscid, white or rose-color, the upper lobes blotched with yellow within. Stamens and styles very long
This is found along streams in both the Coast and Sierra Nevada Mountains

note: oblong, obtuse, 1-2 in. long, in. wide. Flower clusters all terminal. Northern California to British Columbia.
title: Leaves smooth on both sides, but paler and more glandular beneath. Flower clusters often crowded, terminal or axillary. This is common at high elevations in the Sierra Nevada and on the coast from northern California to British Columbia
Leaves densely white-woolly beneath, becoming brownish, margins with the edges turned back
This is common everywhere, and has been introduced from Europe
Trees or shrubs with compound leaves and dioecious or polygamous flowers

author.literal: a. F. dipet'ala Hook. &Arn. FLOWERING ASH.

note: entire, sessile, usually tomentose when young, becoming smooth with age. Flowers without petals. From Fresno County, in the mountains, to Oregon and Washington.
title: Stamens 2, with large anthers. Fruit winged from the top
A small tree or shrub with 5-7 separate leaflets on petioles. Flowers showy, in panicles. Calyx 4-toothed. Petals 2, white, as long as the anthers. This grows along streams in the Coast Mountains
A large tree with darkcolored bark
Leaves twice pinnately divided, with the divisions sharply and irregularly incised. Stem and leaves dark-red when young, becoming greener with age
Flowers an inch long, crimson, in a dense spike that lengthens in fruit. Common in western and middle California

container-title: b. P. lanceola'ta L. Hairy. Leaves long
title: Leaves large, ovate, 5-7-ribbed, the petioles channeled on the upper side. A wayside weed, introduced

note: Scape 2-3 in. high. Flowers in dense oblong spikes, except in very small plants, where they form a head. Widely distributed.
title: Flowers with conspicuous stamens ; at first in a head, lengthening to a spike
Smooth, leaves linear, fleshy. Spike oblong. This is found along the seashore
A small annual covered with white silky wool
This has been made to include many species which are difficult to distinguish
Leaves lanceolate, 3-5 in. long. Heads an inch in diameter, flowers cream-color. Common along streams throughout California, except near the coast
This grows in damp, shady places in the Sierra Nevada Mountains, chiefly northward. in

container-title: This is common in Washington. d. E. macrocar'pa Greene. Fruit oblong
note: densely covered with long, rather soft, stout spines. Seeds several, more than 4-
title: This is a more luxuriant plant than the preceding, and is less common, found chiefly around San Francisco
Fruit ovate-oblong, 1-2 inches long, sparingly clothed with soft spines, with 3-4 cells, each 3-seeded. Fertile flowers with abortive stamens

note: Heads much larger, the involucres shorter than the flowers. Not quite so common as the preceding.
title: Sterns several, slender, erect. Heads rather small, with the involucres as long as the flowers
Stems many

note: The large purple heads are on thick, hollow stems. The flowers soon fade.
title: This is common, having escaped from cultivation
Leaves pinnatifid, tipped with soft spiny teeth, tapering from an auricled base to a long point, the auricles acute, akenes rough. This is a very common introduced weed
Leaves oblong-ovate to broadly lance-shaped, nearly sessile, irregularly toothed. The entire plant has a heavy, aromatic odor

note: Leaves entire, heart-shaped or arrow-shaped, 4-8 in. long, on long petioles.
title: Densely covered with white wool

note: Leaves broadly heart-shaped to V-shaped, irregularly serrate or entire, 4-10 in. long.
title: Scapes a foot or two high. Rays yellow, 1-2 in. long. In the Sierra Nevada Mountains to British Columbia, blooming in early spring
Green and almost smooth
Scapes with small lanceolate or cordate leaves bearing 1-3 heads
Rays an inch or more long. Southern California to British Columbia, blooming in early spring
Annuals with glandular, aromatic foliage and flowers that
This is the only species. It grows in wet places in early spring and often covers the ground for miles along highways

author.particle: a. MUGWORT. Stems simple A. vulga'ris var.

title: Upper leaves toothed or entire, lower 3-5-parted, green on the upper surface, white-woolly below. This grows in gulches and along streams, and is widely distributed

note: Entire plant white-pubescent. Leaves pinnately divided into thread-like divisions.
title: Shrubby, with many branches from a woody base, 3-4 ft. high, forming a clump
This grows on dry hills and is pleasantly aromatic
Annual, with spreading branches

note: Outer bracts of the involucre with 3-5 small prickles, palmately spreading middle bracts with a ;
title: Radical leaves pinnatifid, with rather broad lobes, the stem leaves barely toothed, decurrent. Corollas yellow, inconspicuous. Scales of the involucre spine-tipped, and with a few prickles at the base. Common in fields and waste places
Stem leaves linear. Flowers conspicuous yellow
